Award.AwardTitle: EAAI-13: The Fourth Annual Symposium on Educational Advances in Artificial Intelligence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant provides travel support for selected students attending the annual Symposium on Combinatorial Search (SoCS). Student participation in SoCS encourages young investigators in their research in combinatorial search. This symposium carries on a tradition of bringing together researchers and students around issues of pattern-database heuristics, inconsistent heuristics, real-time search, path-finding for physical robots and computer-game agents, parallel search, and search using external memory. These search techniques have a significant place in broader AI application in areas such as robotics, computer games, planning, and bioinformatics. In addition, SoCS 13 includes a special focus on graph search engineering.

Institution.Name: Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ASSOCIATION FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provides travel support to enable the participation of students at the Fourth Symposium on Educational Advances in Artificial Intelligence (EAAI-13).  The EAAI-13 symposium was held July 15-16, 2013 in Bellevue, Washington. The symposium continues the tradition of being collocated with the national Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) conference. EAAI provides a venue for researchers, educators, graduate students, and others to discuss and present ideas related to the best practices for teaching of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and how AI can be used in teaching concepts in other areas of Computer Science.  EAAI supports the sharing of innovative educational techniques that teach or leverage AI and its many subfields, e.g., robotics, computer vision, natural language processing, machine learning, etc.  EAAI-13 included two invited talks, paper and poster presentations, Model AI assignments, a Teaching and Mentoring Workshop, a panel on educational repositories for teaching AI, an AAAI senior member presentation, and open meeting and discussion time for the attendees. 

An import goal of the symposium is to allow those who are educating the future researchers and practitioners of AI to discuss effective strategies and to share those strategies with the student attendees who often become teaching assistants or future faculty.  The target audience extends to those educators and students who teach at smaller institutions and liberal arts colleges, who use AI as a motivation in their courses without it being a focus of their research, and who serve under-represented groups in STEM disciplines. The symposium also provides a natural point of dissemination for contributors to present their work to attendees as well as a repository of information at the symposium website. An additional result of the symposium was to create a running column in the quarterly AI magazine, available to all members of AAAI, as a place to discuss and share innovative educational approaches that teach or leverage AI and its many subfields.
